questiontext.text:
Example

Do the following series converge or diverge?

  1. \(\sum\limits_{n=1}^\infty \frac{n^2 - 1}{n^2+n}\)
  2. \(\sum\limits_{n=1}^\infty \frac{n - 1}{n^2+n}\)

Solution

  1. We use the divergence test. Here we have \[ \lim\limits_{n \to \infty} \frac{n^2 - 1}{n^2+n} = \lim\limits_{n \to \infty} \frac{1-\frac{1}{n^2}}{1+\frac{1}{n}}=1 \not=0. \] Therefore by the divergence test the series diverges.
  2. We proceed similarly with this series \[ \lim\limits_{n \to \infty} \frac{n - 1}{n^2+n} = \lim\limits_{n \to \infty} \frac{1 - \frac{1}{n}}{n + 1} = \lim\limits_{n \to \infty} \frac{1}{n+1} \to 0 \mbox{ as } n \to \infty. \] Therefore the series passes the divergence test but notice that this does not tell us that the initial series converges. It tells us that we need more information to decide.
